sentence: Salesforce.com ( CRM ) is expected to release its second-quarter results after the market close on August 22.
The consensus calls for earnings of $0.32, versus $0.24 during the same period last year.
The stock has been a top performer in 2017, with shares up 29.1% year to date.
CRM was recently trading at $91.10, down $1.39 from its 12-month high and $24.67 above its 12-month low.
Overall technical indicators for CRM are bullish and the stock is in a strong upward trend.
The stock has recent support above $87.25 and has recent resistance below $92.50.
Of the 27 analysts who cover the stock, 24 rate it a "strong buy", one rates it a "buy", and two rate it a "hold".
The stock receives S&P Capital IQ's 3 STARS "Hold" ranking.
Salesforce has enjoyed a very bullish run over the last year, fueled by a string of better than expected quarterly reports, and strong earnings growth.
The company has managed to outpace analyst estimates for profits each of the last five quarters, and sales have also been better than expected over that same time period.
The stock has an incredible P/E of 480, but analysts do see earnings growth of 28.7% for the current year, and over the next five years see per annum growth of 27.8%.
Salesforce is doing everything right, and despite the high valuation the stock should continue to build on recent gains as long as its quarterly results do not disappoint.

The stock is currently trading at $91.10, and analysts have an average price target of $100.64, so it is clear that the stock's current valuation will not stand in the way of future price appreciation on the heels of a better than expected quarterly report.
If you want a bullish hedged trade on the stock, consider an October 75/80 bull-put credit spread for a 30-cent credit.
That's a potential 6.4% return (37.0% annualized*) and the stock would have to fall 11.9% to cause a problem.
If you want to take a bearish stance on the stock at this time, consider an October 100/105 bear-call credit spread for a $0.50 credit.
That's a potential 11.1% return (64.4% annualized*) and the stock would have to rise 10.3% to cause a problem.
